text: hello I'm Jennifer and this is another

Massachusetts in the previous lesson we

was this sound but now I'd like to talk
about its partner the voice th what am I
talking about what's the difference
voiced/unvoiced well in the first lesson
we said words like mouth cell thin thick
if you take your fingers and place them
on your throat when you get to the th
sound
you should feel no vibration thin thick
mouth cell it's a sound without your
voice now we're going to make the same
sound but add your voice and that's the
voice th let's back up and make sure
we're making the sound correctly I
explained in the first lesson that
you're going to use your teeth and you
take your tongue and you place them
between so that your teeth are gently
touching your tongue then when you blow
out air you need to do so so that the
air can pass over and under and it
sounds like and just the tip of your
tongue is showing between your teeth now
I hope that explanation helped you I
wanted to explain that in practice what
you may find is that the teeth the
bottom teeth may still have contact with
your tongue what's most important is to
let the air pass over your tongue
so if you're still having trouble making
this sound begin by placing the tip of
your tongue between the teeth if
necessary push a little harder on your
upper teeth and then blow out

all right well then let's try this let's

let's say these words this that these
those then there let's write them
familiar words and they all have th at

appear in the middle of words for
example another and a lot of family
members brother father mother these
clothing and clothes as you can guess
our next list will have the voice th at

doing for farms well I think you're

and we can say them together let's begin

brothers another mother this is smooth
the father is there and the last one
bathed them notice how I have two th's
one after the other at the end and at
the beginning instead of saying two th
sounds we're going to make just one and
hold it out a little bit longer so not
bathe them but bathe them good all right
now I have a question for you I have
something to show you and I want you to
guess what these are do you have any
idea hmm well if you've ever been around

teething toys teething toys you know of
course teeth if you add an e it becomes
a verb teeth when babies get their teeth
they are teething so I have a little
text to share with you to practice
teething and some other voiced th words
let me share that with you hope the

all the underlined th's are the voiced
th s these are teething toys for my
children they use them when they are
teething Natasha is a baby she'll need
the teething toys in a few months
her brother Alex used these same toys as
a baby how did you do all right well I
hope that helped again we talked about
the two different th sounds and I hope

one of them is a quiet sound th without
your voice
Livan and the other one you add your
voice the live them same sound
pronounced the same way with the tip of

said if you're still having some trouble
you of course can picture the air
flowing above and below but if it's a
little still difficult most important is
to concentrate on letting the air pass
over your tongue break contact with the
upper teeth and your tongue if you still
have some contact with the lower teeth
you should still get the correct sound
okay well great that's all for now I
